questions.text: A 24-Year-old primigravida with 38 weeks of gestation presents with pain abdomen, backache, contractions, and show. She is a case of type I DM on treatment and well-controlled blood sugar levels. Her previous lab investigations and use are normal. On examination, P-80/min, BP-120/88mmHg, RR-13/min, afebrile, saturation normal, pallor +. Abdominal examination shows fundus just below xiphisternum, vertical lie, cephalic presentation, head engaged, FHR-140/min, contractions 5/10mins. PV examination shows cervix soft, effaced, dilated-7cm, 1.5cm length, head at station +1, membranes absent. NST was normal. The labor was monitored, and after the delivery of the head, the progress of labor wasn't seen. The recoil of the head back against the perineum was seen. The predisposing factors for this condition are ? 1. Diabetes 2. Obesity 3. Midpelvic instrumentation 4. Anencephaly 5. Fetal ascites Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above The given clinical case scenario is that of shoulder dystocia during labor . The recoil of the head back against the perineum refers to the turtle neck sign. Definition: The term shoulder dystocia describes a wide range of additional obstetric maneuvers to deliver the fetus after the head has been born and gentle traction has failed to deliver the shoulder. Shoulder dystocia occurs when either the anterior or the posterior (rare) fetal shoulder impacts the maternal symphysis or the sacral promontory, respectively. Risk factors: 1. Previous shoulder dystocia, 2. Macrosomia ( > 4.5 kg), 3. Diabetes (STATEMENT 1) 4. Obesity (BMI > 30 kg/m2) (STATEMENT2) 5. Induced labor, 6. Prolonged first stage or second stage of labor, 7. Secondary arrest of labor, 8. Postmaturity, 9. Multiparity, 10. Anencephaly (STATEMENT4) 11. Mid-pelvic instrumental delivery (more following ventouse than forceps) (STATEMENT3) 12. Fetal ascites (STATEMENT5)

Highyeild:

Risk factors: Shoulder dystocia can occur in all those conditions where the fetus is too big or in case of mismanaged labor. D-Maternal diabetes O-Maternal obesity and fetal obesity, e., macrosomia P-Post-term pregnancy A-Anencephaly, Fetal ascites

Extraedge:

Call for Help H Call for Help 1st line Evaluate for Episiotomy E End pushing Legs (The McRoberts manoeuvre) L Legs (McRoberts) Suprapubic Pressure P Suprapubic Pressure Enter manoeuvres (internal rotation) E Enter-remove posterior arm/ rotate baby into the oblique 2nd line Remove the posterior arm R Roll over Roll the patient R Refer 3rd line

questions.text: A 24-Year-old primigravida with 38 weeks of gestation presents with pain abdomen, backache, contractions, and show. She is a case of type I DM on treatment and well-controlled blood sugar levels. The labor was monitored, and after the delivery of the head, the progress of labor wasn't seen. The recoil of the head back against the perineum was seen. The management includes all except- 1. Traction over baby's head 2. Fundal pressure 3. Suprapubic pressure 4. McRoberts maneuvered Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1 and 2 The given clinical scenario is that of shoulder dystocia during labor. The recoil of the head back against the perineum describes a turtle neck sign. Management principles: a. Extra help is to be called to clear the infant’s mouth and nose b. Not to give traction over the baby’s head (STATEMENT 1) c. Never apply fundal pressure as it causes further impaction of the shoulder (STATEMENT2) d. McRoberts maneuver – hyperflex maternal hips (knees to chest position) and tell the patient to stop pushing. This widens the pelvic outlet by flattening the sacral promontory and increasing the lumbosacral angle. e. To involve the anesthetist (as analgesia is ideal) and the pediatrician (for infant resuscitation).

Highyeild:

Risk factors: Shoulder dystocia can occur in all those conditions where the fetus is too big or in case of mismanaged labor. D-Maternal diabetes O-Maternal obesity and fetal obesity, i.e., macrosomia P-Post-term pregnancy A-Anencephaly, Fetal ascites

Extraedge:

Call for Help H Call for Help 1st line Evaluate for Episiotomy E End pushing Legs (The McRoberts manoeuvre) L Legs (McRoberts) Suprapubic Pressure P Suprapubic Pressure Enter manoeuvres (internal rotation) E Enter-remove posterior arm/ rotate baby into the oblique 2nd line Remove the posterior arm R Roll over Roll the patient R Refer 3rd line

questions.text: A 24-Year-old primigravida with 38 weeks of gestation presents with pain abdomen, backache, contractions, and show. She is a case of type I DM on treatment and well-controlled blood sugar levels. The labor was monitored, and after the delivery of the head, the progress of labor wasn't seen. The recoil of the head back against the perineum was seen. The obstetrician performs the maneuver shown below. The name of the maneuver is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mc Robert's maneuver The given clinical scenario is that of shoulder dystocia in labor. The Recoil of the head back against the perineum describes the turtle neck sign. The image shown is that of Mc Robert’s maneuver. McRoberts maneuver: Abduct the maternal thighs and sharply hyperflex them onto her abdomen. There is upward rotation of the symphysis pubis and a decrease in the angle of pelvic inclination. This straightens the lumbosacral curve, rotates the maternal pelvis upward, and increases the anterior-posterior diameter of the pelvis. T his maneuver is effective and is successful in about 90 percent of cases. Suprapubic pressure may be used together. This procedure, when possible, may be done first (RCOG-2012)

Highyeild:

Risk factors: S houlder dystocia can occur in all those conditions where the fetus is too big or in case of mismanaged labor. D-Maternal diabetes O-Maternal obesity and fetal obesity, i.e., macrosomia P-Post-term pregnancy A-Anencephaly, Fetal ascites

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Wood’s maneuver: General anesthesia is administered. A corkscrew movement rotates the posterior shoulder to the anterior position (180°). This is done by inserting two fingers in the posterior vagina. Simultaneous suprapubic pressure is applied. This pushes the bis acromial diameter from the anteroposterior diameter to an oblique diameter. This helps ease the entry of the bis acromial diameter into the pelvic inlet. Option: C. Zavanelli maneuver (pushing the fetus back to the uterus and delivering by cesarean section) Option D. Burns Marshall's method is for the separation of the placenta.

Extraedge:

Call for Help H Call for Help 1st line Evaluate for Episiotomy E End pushing Legs (The McRoberts manoeuvre) L Legs (McRoberts) Suprapubic Pressure P Suprapubic Pressure Enter manoeuvres (internal rotation) E Enter-remove posterior arm/ rotate baby into the oblique 2nd line Remove the posterior arm R Roll over Roll the patient R Refer 3rd line

questions.text: A 26-Year-old primigravida with 38 weeks of gestation presents with pain abdomen, contractions, leak pv, and show. She is a case of Gestational diabetes and hypertension on treatment. Her previous use was normal, with the child's weight at 3.8kg. The arrest of labor after the delivery of the head was seen. The obstetrician performs abduction of the maternal thighs and hyperflexion but does not help. The next maneuver performed is shown below which is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Wood's maneuver The given clinical scenario points towards shoulder dystocia during labor in a case of gestational hypertension and diabetes. The maneuver described in the question is McRoberts, which is the first procedure for shoulder dystocia. The given image shows Wood’s corkscrew maneuver. Wood’s maneuver: General anesthesia is administered. A corkscrew movement rotates the posterior shoulder to the anterior position (180°). This is done by inserting two fingers in the posterior vagina. Simultaneous suprapubic pressure is applied. This pushes the bis acromial diameter from the anteroposterior diameter to an oblique diameter. This helps ease the entry of the bis acromial diameter into the pelvic inlet.

Highyeild:

Risk factors: Shoulder dystocia can occur in all those conditions where the fetus is too big or in case of mismanaged labor. D-Maternal diabetes O-Maternal obesity and fetal obesity, e., macrosomia P-Post-term pregnancy A-Anencephaly, Fetal ascites

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Zavanelli maneuver (pushing the fetus back to the uterus and delivering by cesarean section) Option: A. McRoberts maneuver: Abduct the maternal thighs and sharply hyperflex them onto her abdomen. There is upward rotation of the symphysis pubis and a decrease in the angle of pelvic inclination. This straightens the lumbosacral curve, rotates the maternal pelvis upward, and increases the anterior-posterior diameter of the pelvis. This maneuver is effective and is successful in about 90 percent of cases. Suprapubic pressure may be used together. This procedure, when possible, may be done first (RCOG-2012)

Extraedge:

questions.text: A 26-Year-old primigravida with 39 weeks of gestation presents with a history of pain abdomen, showing contractions and leaks. She is a case of gestational diabetes on treatment. Her previous use was normal, and the baby weighed 3.6kg. After a few minutes, the labor was noted to be arrested after the delivery of the head. Match the following maneuvers done by the obstetrician for the delivery accordingly; Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1=d, 2=a, 3=c, 4=b McRoberts maneuver: Abduct the maternal thighs and sharply hyperflex them onto her abdomen. There is upward rotation of the symphysis pubis and a decrease in the angle of pelvic inclination. This straightens the lumbosacral curve, rotates the maternal pelvis upward, and increases the anterior-posterior diameter of the pelvis. This maneuver is effective and is successful in about 90 percent of cases. Suprapubic pressure may be used together. This procedure, when possible, may be done first (RCOG-2012) Wood’s maneuver: General anesthesia is administered. A corkscrew movement rotates the posterior shoulder to the anterior position (180°). This is done by inserting two fingers in the posterior vagina. Simultaneous suprapubic pressure is applied. This pushes the bis acromial diameter from the anteroposterior diameter to an oblique diameter. This helps ease the entry of the bis acromial diameter into the pelvic inlet. Zavanelli maneuver (pushing the fetus back to the uterus and delivering by cesarean section) Extraction of the posterior arm: The operator’s hand is introduced into the vagina along the fetal posterior humerus in the sacral hollow . The component is then swept across the chest and after that delivered by gentle traction. This procedure may cause either a fracture clavicle or humerus or both.

Highyeild:

Risk factors: Shoulder dystocia can occur in all those conditions where the fetus is too big or in case of mismanaged labor. D-Maternal diabetes O-Maternal obesity and fetal obesity, i.e., macrosomia P-Post-term pregnancy A-Anencephaly, Fetal ascites

Extraedge:

Call for Help H Call for Help 1st line Evaluate for Episiotomy E End pushing Legs (The McRoberts manoeuvre) L Legs (McRoberts) Suprapubic Pressure P Suprapubic Pressure Enter manoeuvres (internal rotation) E Enter-remove posterior arm/ rotate baby into the oblique 2nd line Remove the posterior arm R Roll over Roll the patient R Refer 3rd line

questions.text: Sudden hyperflexion of the thigh over the abdomen(MC Roberts maneuver) with of the following nerve is commonly involved?
questions.correct_answer: D. Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh MC Roberts’ maneuver consists of forcibly abducting the patient's legs by sharply flexing them on the abdomen. It is the single most effective maneuver and should be the first to perform in case of shoulder dystocia. McRoberts maneuver results in the straightening of the sacrum relative to the lumbar vertebra along with the rotation of symphysis pubis towards the maternal head, decreasing the pelvic inclination angle. Sometimes, overzealous use of the McRoberts maneuver may result in the separation of the maternal pubic symphysis and injury to the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh.

Highyeild:

Risk factors: Shoulder dystocia can occur in all those conditions where the fetus is too big or in case of mismanaged labor. D-Maternal diabetes O-Maternal obesity and fetal obesity, i.e. macrosomia P-Post-term pregnancy A-Anencephaly, Fetal ascites

Extraedge:
